subject: Ansible playbooks and roles to deploy OpenStack
commit_message:
Ansible playbooks and roles to deploy OpenStack

Request to add the os-ansible-deployment project to OpenStack namespace.
os-ansible-deployment (OSAD) is a project dedicated to deploying OpenStack
clouds using Ansible and upstream OpenStack source code without the addition
of vendor driven packaging.

This project is already using all of the OpenStack infrastructure and services
and is gated through gerrit with testing being done on the whole stack using
tempest on our three supported branches.

We are committed to furthering our mission of a great
developer/deployer/operator experience and intend to build out the system to
support all of the OpenStack named services.

We use the OpenStack dev/operators mailing list (albeit infrequently) and hold
meetings twice weekly[1] (one in our channel and the other in an official
OpenStack meeting channel which is logged[2]).

The IRC channel #openstack-ansible is logged[3], and active with community
members, core developers and like minted people all helping and disusing issues
within the project as well as questions that come us from using Ansible to
operate and manage clouds.

The scope of os-ansible-deployment is to provide tooling for deploying OpenStack
using ansible which will include contributing to the efforts of upstream
Ansible. We are already working with the community to ensure that our efforts
are not duplicated or being made in direct contrast to what upstream Ansible is
already providing. While we do have some overlap within our currently carried
modules, the OpenStack client modules we have in tree, we are committed to moving
that functionality and code into upstream just as we've done with our other
plugins/modules[4][5].

With this project's move to "big tent" we'd only be looking to bring with us the
Master and Kilo branches as they've been designed to be community code with
all of the original Rackspace-isms removed. This would mean that the Juno and
Icehouse branches would be left behind in StackForge as they'd not be part of
the mainline project but we, the community of developers working on OSAD, will
be supporting those code bases until they're EOL'd by the upstream OpenStack
projects.

This commit is a formal request to add os-ansible-deployment into the
OpenStack namespace as an official project.

[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/openstack_ansible_meeting/
[3] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ansible/
[4] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/9927

subject: Disable allowed_address_pair ip 0.0.0.0/0 ::/0 for ipset
commit_message:
Disable allowed_address_pair ip 0.0.0.0/0 ::/0 for ipset

Previously, the ipset_manager would pass in 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 if
these addresses were inputted as allowed address pairs. This causes
ipset to raise an error as it does not work with zero prefix sizes.
To solve this problem we use two ipset rules to represent this.

This was correctly fixed in a backport to kilo though we did not have the
cycles to backport this exact fix to juno as in juno additional work needs to
be done because the iptable and ipset code are interleaved together. This
patch fixes this issue by disabling one from creating an address pair of
zero lenght. This patch also provides a small tool which one should run:
tools/fix_zero_length_ip_prefix.py which changes all zero length address_pair
rules into two address pair rules of:

Ipv4: 0.0.0.0/1 and 128.0.0.1/1
IPv6: ::/1' and '8000::/1

to avoid the problem.
After this patch is merged into juno it will be easier for us to apply
a better change to allow /0 addresses again in juno.

Change-Id: I8c6a08e0cf3b5b5386fe03af9f2174c666b8ac75
Closes-bug: 1461054

subject: API: Get a subset of fields from Nodes
commit_message:
API: Get a subset of fields from Nodes

Sometimes we don't care about all fields in a node (or a collection
of them) and only need a particular subset of fields for a particular
operation. This can save a lot of bandwidth depending on the information
contained in the nodes, for example, a node which contains a config drive
bsae64 encoded in it's instance_info field can be pretty heavy (a
collection of them ...)

This patch allows users to specify a list of fields that will be returned
when GET'ing a node or a collection of nodes.

E.g

Get the uuid, provision_state and power_state of a particular node:

  GET v1/nodes/<uuid>?fields=uuid,provision_state,power_state

Get the uuid, provision_state and power_state of a collection of nodes:

  GET v1/nodes?fields=uuid,provision_state,power_state

Get the uuid, provision_state and power_state of a particular node associated
with a particular instance:

  GET v1/nodes?fields=uuid,provision_state,power_state&instance_uuid=<instance uuid>

Since we are introducing a new feature in the API this patch bumps the
micro version to 1.8

subject: Get better at closing WSGI iterables.
commit_message:
Get better at closing WSGI iterables.

PEP 333 (WSGI) says: "If the iterable returned by the application has
a close() method, the server or gateway must call that method upon
completion of the current request[.]"

There's a bunch of places where we weren't doing that; some of them
matter more than others. Calling .close() can prevent a connection
leak in some cases. In others, it just provides a certain pedantic
smugness. Either way, we should do what WSGI requires.

Noteworthy goofs include:

  * If a client is downloading a large object and disconnects halfway
    through, a proxy -> obj connection may be leaked. In this case,
    the WSGI iterable is a SegmentedIterable, which lacked a close()
    method. Thus, when the WSGI server noticed the client disconnect,
    it had no way of telling the SegmentedIterable about it, and so
    the underlying iterable for the segment's data didn't get
    closed.

    Here, it seems likely (though unproven) that the object server
    would time out and kill the connection, or that a
    ChunkWriteTimeout would fire down in the proxy server, so the
    leaked connection would eventually go away. However, a flurry of
    client disconnects could leave a big pile of useless connections.

  * If a conditional request receives a 304 or 412, the underlying
    app_iter is not closed. This mostly affects conditional requests
    for large objects.

The leaked connections were noticed by this patch's co-author, who
made the changes to SegmentedIterable. Those changes helped, but did
not completely fix, the issue. The rest of the patch is an attempt to
plug the rest of the holes.

Co-Authored-By: Romain LE DISEZ <romain.ledisez@ovh.net>

Closes-Bug: #1466549

The wait_for_servers helper in glance.tests.functional.FunctionTest
uses the strace(1). While strace(1) is available on FreeBSD, but with a
huge limitation that it works only on i386 hosts.

Instead of always using strace(1), use it only on Linux, for FreeBSD use
the truss(1) tool, that is a native tracing tool that is a part of base
system, and in all other cases just don't try to obtain a trace.

Closes-bug: #1467110
Change-Id: I51cc43fe4ce71eed80bbf4f18f5b060b09494458

subject: Use *.pot files for source language
commit_message:
Use *.pot files for source language

All other OpenStack projects use *.pot files for the source language.
In the OpenStack CI scripts, we need to special case horizon since
it uses */locale/en/LC_MESSAGES/*po instead. Remove the special handling
from the horizon scripts so that we can simplify the CI scripts.

Note that this simplifies also the run_tests.sh script.

Add empty files for the pot files so that the infra scripts will work.
The next import from the Proposol Bot will add real content for these
files.

Change-Id: I2ae68207994ba549b5d8e551a40a468d63e0a4bb
